title: 111_hr5631
content: The Act may be cited as the "Gulf Coast Conservation Corps Act of 2010". The Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico is the worst environmental disaster in US history, with BP unable to stop the oil discharge. The fishing industry, supporting over 200,000 jobs and $5.5 billion in economic activity, is heavily impacted. As of May 25, 2010, fishing was banned in a 54,096 square-mile area of the Gulf Exclusive Economic Zone. The tourist industry in the Gulf region provided 620,000 jobs and over $9 billion in wages. The oil spill cleanup will require a dedicated workforce over an extended period. Contracts and agreements between Federal agencies and local governments are cost-effective tools for restoring public land affected by the BP oil spill. Collaborations between Federal agencies, private businesses, and service corps are beneficial for rehabilitating public land affected by the BP oil spill and conserving important land and water. This partnership provides opportunities for productive and educational public service while saving costs on human resources for land conservation. The Gulf Coast Conservation Corps aims to rehabilitate areas affected by the Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, create jobs for unemployed individuals in environmental restoration, and provide opportunities for community service. The Gulf Coast Conservation Corps, administered by the President, will carry out rehabilitation and enhancement projects in the Gulf of Mexico affected by the Deepwater Horizon oil spill. Participants must be unemployed individuals. The Gulf Coast Conservation Corps, administered by the President, will carry out rehabilitation and enhancement projects in the Gulf of Mexico affected by the Deepwater Horizon oil spill. Participants must be unemployed individuals who are citizens or legal permanent residents of the United States, physically capable of the work required, and not enrolled as full-time students in any higher education institution. Individuals in the Gulf Coast Conservation Corps must not displace other employees, will be compensated at rates similar to employees in similar occupations, and will not be considered federal employees. The President may enter contracts with various organizations to administer the Corps and provide technical assistance to the Corps. The President may contract organizations to administer the Corps, provide technical assistance, monitor compliance, consult with international authorities, and conduct research for project development. The Act's costs will be covered by the Oil Spill Liability Trust Fund, as per the Oil Pollution Act of 1990. Definitions are provided in the Act. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. This section provides definitions for key terms used in the Act, such as "discharge," "oil," "removal," "institution of higher education," "national service laws," and "State." Authorization of appropriations for $15,000,000 for fiscal years 2011 and 2012 is provided to carry out the Act.
